properties.name: Battle of the Atlantic - September 3, 1939 - May 7, 1945
properties.description:
The Battle of the Atlantic was the longest continuous military campaign of World War II, (though some say it was a series of naval military campaigns and offensives running from 1939 through to the defeat of Nazi Germany in 1945, and was at its height from mid-1940 through to the end of 1943. The Battle of the Atlantic pitted U-boats and other warships of the German Navy (Kriegsmarine) against Allied convoys. The convoys, coming mainly from North America and the South Atlantic and going to the United Kingdom and the Soviet Union, were protected for the most part by the British and Canadian navies and air forces. These forces were aided by ships and aircraft of the United States from 13 September 1941. The Germans were joined by submarines of the Italian Royal Navy (Regia Marina) after Italy entered the war on June 10, 1940.
(Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_the_Atlantic_%281939%E2%80%931945%29)

More World War II Resources: http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Siege of Leningrad - September 8, 1941 - January 27, 1944
properties.description:
The Siege of Leningrad, also known as The Leningrad Blockade was an unsuccessful military operation by the Axis powers to capture Leningrad (now Saint Petersburg) during World War II. The siege started at 8 September 1941, when the last land connection to the city was severed. Although Soviets managed to open a narrow land corridor to the city at 18 January 1943, the total lifting of the siege happened at 27 January 1944, 872 days after it began. The Siege of Leningrad was one of the longest and most destructive sieges of major cities in modern history and it was the third most costly in terms of casualties. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Siege_of_Leningrad)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Battle of Stalingrad - July 17, 1942 - February 2, 1943
properties.description:
The Battle of Stalingrad was a battle of World War II between Nazi Germany and its allies and the Soviet Union for control of the city of Stalingrad in southwestern Russia. The battle took place between 17 July 1942 and 2 February 1943.
(Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Stalingrad)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Tunisia Campaign - November 17, 1942 - May 13, 1943
properties.description:
The Tunisia Campaign (also known as the Battle of Tunisia) was a series of World War II battles that took place in Tunisia in the North African Campaign of World War II, between Axis and Allied forces. The Allies consisted primarily of British Imperial Forces along with American and the French Army. The battle opened with initial success by the German and Italian forces, but the massive supply and numerical superiority of the Allies led to the Axis' complete defeat. Over 230,000 German and Italian troops were taken as prisoners of war, including most of the Afrika Korps. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tunisia_Campaign)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Velikiye Luki Offensive - November 19, 1942 - January 16, 1943
properties.description:
The Velikiye Luki offensive operation was executed by the forces of the Red Army's Kalinin Front against the Wehrmacht's 3rd Panzer Army during the Winter Campaign of 1942-1943 with the objective of liberating the Russian city of Velikiye Luki as part of the northern pincer of the Rzhev-Sychevka Strategic Offensive Operation (Operation Mars). (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_for_Velikiye_Luki_%281943%29)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Soviet North Caucasian Strategic Offensive - January 1 - February 4, 1943
properties.description:
The Soviet North Caucasian Strategic Offensive Operation (1 January 1943 - 4 February 1943) was launched with the objective of removing threat of German bombing of the oil fields. The operation consisted of operations with more limited operational objectives. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_the_Caucasus)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Operation Iskra - January 12 - 30, 1943
properties.description:
Operation Iskra was a Soviet military operation conducted by the Red Army's Leningrad and Volkhov Fronts, and the Baltic Fleet during January 12 - January 30, 1943 with the aim of creating a land connection to Leningrad, in order to raise the German Wehrmacht siege of the city. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Operation_Iskra)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Battle of Nikolayevka - January 13 - 26, 1943
properties.description:
The Battle of Nikolayevka was fought in January of 1943, as a small part of the larger Battle of Stalingrad. The Battle pitted forces of the Italian 8th Army's Alpini Corps against the four Soviet Armies of the Voronezh Front. Since the war the village has been absorbed by the nearby village of Livenka. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Nikolayevka)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Battle of Voronezh - January 15 - 25, 1943
properties.description:
The 1943 battle of Voronezh (often credited in Russian as the liberation of Voronezh ) was a Soviet counter-offensive on recapturing the city of Voronezh during the Ostrogozhsk-Rossoshansk and Voronezh-Kastornensk operations on the Eastern Front of World War II. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Voronezh_%281943%29)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Battle of Krasny Bor - February 9 - 13, 1943
properties.description:
The Battle of Krasny Bor was fought between the German Wehrmacht's 250th Infantry Division, composed of Spanish volunteers, and the Soviet 55th Army by the village of Krasny Bor, Leningrad Oblast, northern Russia. The major clash took place on Wednesday, 10 February 1943. In Spain, it has become known as "Black Wednesday", due to the huge losses of the Spanish division in the battle. It was the most costly battle in which the Spanish volunteers participated on the eastern front. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Krasny_Bor)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Battle of Sidi Bou Zid - February 14 - 17, 1943
properties.description:
The Battle of Sidi Bou Zid was a World War II battle that took place during the Tunisia Campaign. The battle was fought between forces of Nazi Germany and forces of the United States. The German forces included the 10th Panzer Division and the 21st Panzer Division of the Fifth Panzer Army commanded by Colonel General (Generaloberst) Hans-Jurgen von Arnim. The American forces included the 1st Armored Division of the II Corps commanded by General Lloyd Fredendall. The battle was fought around Sidi Bou Zid in northeast Tunisia near Tunis. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Sidi_Bou_Zid)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Battle of the Kasserine Pass - February 19 - 25, 1943
properties.description:
The Battle of the Kasserine Pass took place in World War II during the Tunisia Campaign. It was, in fact, a series of battles fought around Kasserine Pass, a two-mile (3 km) wide gap in the Grand Dorsal chain of the Atlas Mountains in west central Tunisia. The Axis forces involved were primarily from the German-Italian Panzer Army (the redesignated German Panzer Army Africa) led by Field Marshal Erwin Rommel and two Panzer divisions attached from the Fifth Panzer Army. The Allied forces involved came mostly from the U.S. Army's II Corps commanded by Major General Lloyd Fredendall, which was part of the British First Army commanded by Lieutenant-General Kenneth Anderson.
(Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_the_Kasserine_Pass)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Third Battle of Kharkov - February 19 - March 15, 1943
properties.description:
The Third Battle of Kharkov was a series of offensive operations on the Eastern Front of World War II, undertaken by the German Army Group South against the Red Army, around the city of Kharkov between 19 February and 15 March 1943. Known to the Germans as the Donets Campaign, and to the Soviets as the Donbas and Kharkov operations, the German counterstrike led to the destruction of approximately 52 Soviet divisions and the recapture of the cities of Kharkov and Belgorod.
(Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Third_Battle_of_Kharkov)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Operation Capri - March 6, 1943
properties.description:
Operation Capri was a Nazi German counter-attack at Medenine, Tunisia, intended to disrupt and delay the 8th Army's attack on the Mareth Line. The German attack started on 6 March 1943, failed to make much impression and was abandoned at dusk on the same day. Over the next day or two, German forces withdrew northwards. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Operation_Capri)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Battle of Sokolovo - March 8 - 9, 1943
properties.description:
Battle of Sokolovo took place on March 8 and 9, 1943 around the town of Sokolovo near Kharkiv in Ukraine where the on-going attack of Wehrmacht was halted by joint Soviet and Czechoslovak forces. It was for the first time that a foreign military unit, 1st Czechoslovak Battailion fought together with the Red Army. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Sokolovo)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Operation Pugilist - March 16 - 27, 1943
properties.description:
Operation Pugilist was an Allied operation in Tunisia during World War II. Pugilist itself was indecisive and failed to make a decisive breakthrough. It did, however, establish an alternative route of attack and thus laid the ground for Supercharge II, an outflanking maneuver via the Tebaga Gap. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Operation_Pugilist)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Battle of El Guettar - March 23 - April 7, 1943
properties.description:
The Battle of El Guettar was a World War II battle that took place during the Tunisia Campaign, fought between elements of the Army Group Afrika under Jürgen von Arnim and U.S. II Corps under Major General George Patton in south-central Tunisia. It was the first battle in which U.S. forces were able to defeat the experienced German tank units, but the followup to the battle was inconclusive. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_El_Guettar)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: 1st Taman Offensive Operation - April 4 - May 10, 1943
properties.description:
The Taman Peninsula was cleared from the Germans in early October during the 1st Taman Offensive Operation (4 April 1943 - 10 May 1943) but due to a German counterattack the Red Army was forced on the defensive again during 26 May 1943 - 22 August 1944. This was however followed up with a new Novorossiysk-Taman Strategic Offensive Operation (10 September 1943 - 9 October 1943) which, following the Novorossiysk Amphibious Operation (10 September 1943 - 16 September 1943) resulted in the successful 2nd Taman Offensive Operation (10 September 1943 - 9 October 1943). (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_the_Caucasus)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Operation Vulcan - April 22 - May 13, 1943
properties.description:
During World War II, Operation Vulcan was the final ground attack against German forces in Tunis, Cap Bon, and Bizerte, Tunisia, the last Axis toeholds in North Africa. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Operation_Vulcan)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Battle of Kursk - July 4 - August 23, 1943
properties.description:
The Battle of Kursk refers to German and Soviet operations on the Eastern Front of World War II in the vicinity of the city of Kursk in July and August 1943. It remains both the largest series of armoured clashes, including the Battle of Prokhorovka, and the costliest single day of aerial warfare to date. It was the last strategic offensive the Germans were able to mount in the east. The resulting decisive Soviet victory gave the Red Army the strategic initiative for the rest of the war.
(Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Kursk)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Operation Husky - July 9 - August 17, 1943
properties.description:
The Allied invasion of Sicily, codenamed Operation Husky, was a major World War II campaign, in which the Allies took Sicily from the Axis (Italy and Nazi Germany). It was a large scale amphibious and airborne operation, followed by six weeks of land combat. It launched the Italian Campaign. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Allied_invasion_of_Sicily)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Italian Campaign - July 10, 1943 - May 8, 1945
properties.description:
The Italian Campaign of World War II was the name of Allied operations in and around Italy, from 1943 to the end of the war. Joint Allied Forces Headquarters AFHQ was operationally responsible for all Allied land forces in the Mediterranean theatre, and it planned and commanded the invasion of Sicily and the campaign on the Italian mainland until the surrender of German forces in Italy in May 1945.
(Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Italian_Campaign_%28World_War_II%29)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Battle of Prokhorovka - July 12, 1943
properties.description:
The Battle of Prokhorovka was a battle fought by the German Wehrmacht's Fourth Panzer Army and the Soviet Red Army's 5th Guards Tank Army on the Eastern Front during the Second World War. It is one of the largest tank battles in military history. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Prokhorovka)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Operation Kutuzov - July 12 - August 18, 1943
properties.description:
Operation Kutuzov was a military operation by the Red Army in its fight against the German Wehrmacht during World War II. The Operation began on 12 July and ended on 18 August 1943 with the destruction of the Orel bulge, in which the Western and Bryansk fronts defeated the 2 Panzerarmee in its fortified positions around Orel. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Operation_Kutuzov)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Battle of Belgorod - July 23 - August 14, 1943
properties.description:
The Belgorod-Bogodukhov Offensive Operation (23 July – 14 August 1943) was a combat operation executed as part of Operation Polkovodets Rumyantsev by the Red Army against the Wehrmacht forces. It was one of the operations that followed the Battle of Kursk. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Belgorod)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Battle of Smolensk (1943) - August 7 - October 2, 1943
properties.description:
The second Battle of Smolensk (7 August 1943 – 2 October 1943) was a Soviet strategic offensive operation conducted by the Red Army as part of the Summer-Autumn Campaign of 1943 in the Western USSR. Staged almost simultaneously with the Lower Dnieper Offensive (13 August – 22 September), the offensive lasted two months and was led by Generals Andrei Yeremenko commanding the Kalinin Front and Vasily Sokolovsky commanding the Western Front. Its goal was to clear the Nazi Germany presence from the Smolensk and Bryansk regions. Smolensk had been under German occupation since the first Battle of Smolensk in 1941.
(Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Smolensk_%281943%29)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Belgorod-Khar'kov Offensive - August 12 - 23, 1943
properties.description:
The Belgorod-Khar'kov Offensive Operation (12 August 1943 - 23 August 1943) was an operation conducted as part of Operation Polkovodets Rumyantsev between the Red Army and Wehrmacht forces. It was one of the operations that followed the Battle of Kursk. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Belgorod-Khar%27kov_Offensive_Operation)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Melitopol Offensive, Lower Dnieper Offensive - August 24 - December 23, 1943
properties.description:
The Lower Dnieper Offensive (also known as the "Battle of the Lower Dnieper") of took place in 1943 during the Second World War. It was one of the largest Second World War operations, involving almost 4,000,000 troops on both sides and stretching on a 1400 kilometers long front. During this four-month operation, the eastern bank of the Dnieper was recovered from German forces by five of the Red Army's Fronts, which conducted several river assault crossings to establish several bridgeheads on the western bank. Subsequently, Kiev was liberated in a separate offensive. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lower_Dnieper_Offensive)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Zaporozhye Offensive, Lower Dnieper Offensive - August 24 - December 23, 1943
properties.description:
The Lower Dnieper Offensive (also known as the "Battle of the LowerDnieper") of took place in 1943 during the Second World War. It was oneof the largest Second World War operations, involving almost 4,000,000troops on both sides and stretching on a 1400 kilometers long front.During this four-month operation, the eastern bank of the Dnieper wasrecovered from German forces by five of the Red Army's Fronts, whichconducted several river assault crossings to establish severalbridgeheads on the western bank. Subsequently, Kiev was liberated in aseparate offensive. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lower_Dnieper_Offensive)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Pyatikhatki Offensive, Lower Dnieper Offensive - August 24 - December 23, 1943
properties.description:
The Lower Dnieper Offensive (also known as the "Battle of the LowerDnieper") of took place in 1943 during the Second World War. It was oneof the largest Second World War operations, involving almost 4,000,000troops on both sides and stretching on a 1400 kilometers long front.During this four-month operation, the eastern bank of the Dnieper wasrecovered from German forces by five of the Red Army's Fronts, whichconducted several river assault crossings to establish severalbridgeheads on the western bank. Subsequently, Kiev was liberated in aseparate offensive. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lower_Dnieper_Offensive)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Znamianka Offensive, Lower Dnieper Offensive - August 24 - December 23, 1943
properties.description:
The Lower Dnieper Offensive (also known as the "Battle of the LowerDnieper") of took place in 1943 during the Second World War. It was oneof the largest Second World War operations, involving almost 4,000,000troops on both sides and stretching on a 1400 kilometers long front.During this four-month operation, the eastern bank of the Dnieper wasrecovered from German forces by five of the Red Army's Fronts, whichconducted several river assault crossings to establish severalbridgeheads on the western bank. Subsequently, Kiev was liberated in aseparate offensive. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lower_Dnieper_Offensive)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Dnepropetrovsk Offensive, Lower Dnieper Offensive - August 24 - December 23, 1943
properties.description:
The Lower Dnieper Offensive (also known as the "Battle of the LowerDnieper") of took place in 1943 during the Second World War. It was oneof the largest Second World War operations, involving almost 4,000,000troops on both sides and stretching on a 1400 kilometers long front.During this four-month operation, the eastern bank of the Dnieper wasrecovered from German forces by five of the Red Army's Fronts, whichconducted several river assault crossings to establish severalbridgeheads on the western bank. Subsequently, Kiev was liberated in aseparate offensive. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lower_Dnieper_Offensive)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Operation Baytown - September 3, 1943
properties.description:
Operation Baytown was a part of the Allied invasion of Italy during World War II on 3 September 1943. The operation consisted of the landing by sea of the British 13th Corps of British 8th Army at Reggio di Calabria. This allowed the Allied forces to get a foothold at the "toe" of Italy.
Operation Baytown would be followed by Operation Slapstick and Operation Avalanche. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Operation_Baytown)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Operation Avalanche - September 3- 16, 1943
properties.description:
The Allied invasion of Italy, was the Allied landing on mainland Italy on September 3, 1943, by General Harold Alexander's 15th Army Group (comprising Mark Clark's U.S. Fifth Army and Bernard Montgomery's British Eighth Army) during World War II. The operation followed the successful invasion of Sicily during the Italian Campaign. The main invasion force landed around Salerno on the western coast in Operation Avalanche, while two supporting operations took place in Calabria (Operation Baytown) and Taranto (Operation Slapstick). (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Allied_invasion_of_italy)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Operation Slapstick - September 9, 1943
properties.description:
Operation Slapstick was a part of the Allied invasion of Italy during World War II on 9 September 1943. The operation consisted of the landing by sea of the British 1st Airborne Division at Taranto, an important naval base. The US Fifth Army also landed at Salerno on the same day. Allied troops had previously occupied the "toe" of Italy in Operation Baytown. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Operation_Slapstick)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Novorossiysk-Taman Strategic Offensive Operation - September 10 - October 9, 1943
properties.description:
The Taman Peninsula was cleared from the Germans in early October during the 1st Taman Offensive Operation (4 April 1943 - 10 May 1943) but due to a German counterattack the Red Army was forced on the defensive again during 26 May 1943 - 22 August 1944. This was however followed up with a new Novorossiysk-Taman Strategic Offensive Operation (10 September 1943 - 9 October 1943) which, following the Novorossiysk Amphibious Operation (10 September 1943 - 16 September 1943) resulted in the successful 2nd Taman Offensive Operation (10 September 1943 - 9 October 1943). (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_the_Caucasus)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Battle of Kiev - October 3 - December 22, 1943
properties.description:
The 1943 Battle of Kiev describes three strategic operations (two offensive and one defensive) by the Soviet Red Army, and one operational counterattack by the Wehrmacht which took place in the wake of the failed German offensive at Kursk during the Second World War. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Kiev_%281943%29)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Kerch-Eltigen Operation - November 1 - December 11, 1943
properties.description:
The Kerch-Eltigen Operation was a World War II amphibious offensive made in November 1943 by the Red Army as a precursor to the Crimean Offensive Operation (8 April 1944 - 12 May 1944) with the object of liberating the Crimea from German occupation. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kerch-Eltigen_Operation)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Moro River Campaign - December 4 - 26, 1943
properties.description:
The Moro River Campaign was a military campaign during the Second World War fought between units of the British Eighth Army and the LXXVI Panzer Corps of the German Tenth Army. Lasting from 4–26 December 1943, the campaign occurred primarily in the vicinity of the Moro River in eastern Italy. The campaign was designed as part of an offensive launched by General Harold Alexander with the intention of breaching the German Winter Line defensive system and advancing to Pescara—and eventually Rome. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Moro_River_Campaign)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Battle of San Pietro Infine -  December 8 - 17, 1943
properties.description:
The Battle of San Pietro Infine (commonly referred to as the "Battle of San Pietro") was a major engagement from 8–17 December, 1943, in the Italian Campaign of World War II involving Allied Forces attacking from the south against heavily fortified positions of the German "Winter Line" in and around the town of San Pietro Infine, just south of Monte Cassino about halfway between Naples and Rome. The eventual Allied victory in the battle was crucial in the ultimate drive to the north to liberate Rome. The battle is also remembered as the first in which the troops of the Italian Royal Army fought as co-belligerents of the Allies following the armistice with Italy. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_San_Pietro_Infine)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Dnieper–Carpathian Offensive - December 24, 1943 - April 14, 1944
properties.description:
The Dnieper–Carpathian Offensive, also known in Soviet historical sources as the liberation of right-bank Ukraine, fought from 24 December 1943–14 April 1944, was a strategic offensive executed by the 1st, 2nd, 3rd, and 4th Ukrainian Fronts, along with the 1st Belorussian Front, against the German Army Group South, and was intended to retake all of the Ukrainian and Moldovian territories occupied by Axis forces. The operation brought the Red Army forces into Poland and Romania, completely destroyed 18 Wehrmacht and Romanian divisions, and reduced another 68 to below half of their establishment strength. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dnieper%E2%80%93Carpathian_Offensive)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Krasnoye Selo–Ropsha Offensive - January 14 - 30, 1944
properties.description:
The Krasnoye Selo–Ropsha Offensive, also known as Operation January Thunder and Neva-2 was a campaign between the Soviet Leningrad Front and the German 18th Army fought for the western approaches of Leningrad in 14–30 January 1944. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Krasnoye_Selo%E2%80%93Ropsha_Offensive)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Battle of Monte Cassino - January 17, 1944 - May 18, 1944
properties.description:
The Battle of Monte Cassino (also known as the Battle for Rome and the Battle for Cassino) was a costly series of four battles during World War II, fought by the Allies with the intention of breaking through the Winter Line and seizing Rome.
(Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Monte_Cassino)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Operation Shingle - January 22 - June 5, 1944
properties.description:
Operation Shingle (January 22, 1944), during the Italian Campaign of World War II, was an Allied amphibious landing against Axis forces in the area of Anzio and Nettuno, Italy. The operation was commanded by Major General John P. Lucas and was intended to outflank German forces of the Winter Line and enable an attack on Rome. The resulting combat is commonly called the Battle of Anzio. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Operation_Shingle)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Korsun–Shevchenkovsky Offensive - January 24 - February 16, 1944
properties.description:
The Korsun–Shevchenkovsky Offensive led to the Battle of the Korsun-Cherkassy Pocket which took place from 24 January to 16 February, 1944. The offensive was part of the Dnieper–Carpathian Offensive. In it, the 1st and 2nd Ukrainian Fronts, commanded, respectively, by Nikolai Vatutin and Ivan Konev, trapped German forces of Army Group South in a pocket near the Dnieper river. During weeks of fighting, the two Red Army Fronts tried to eradicate the pocket. German units inside the cauldron broke out in coordination with a relief attempt by other German forces, with “roughly two out of three” encircled men succeeding in escaping the pocket, "and almost one third of their men ... dead or prisoners." (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Korsun-Cherkassy_Pocket)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Battle of Cisterna - January 30 - February 2, 1944
properties.description:
The Battle of Cisterna took place during World War II, on January 30 to February 2, 1944, near Cisterna, Italy, as part of the battle of Anzio that followed Operation Shingle. The battle was a clear German victory which also had repurcussions on the employment of U.S. Army Rangers that went beyond the immediate tactical and strategic results of the battle. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Cisterna)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Battle of Narva Bridgehead - February 2 - July 26, 1944
properties.description:
The Battle of Narva Bridgehead (2 February – 26 July 1944) was the campaign that stalled the Soviet Estonian Operation in the surroundings of the town of Narva for five and a half months. It was the first phase of the Battle of Narva campaign fought at the Eastern Front during World War II.
(Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_for_Narva_Bridgehead)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Battle of Narva - February 2 - August 10, 1944
properties.description:
The Battle of Narva was a military campaign between the German army detachment "Narwa" and the Soviet Leningrad Front fought for the strategically important Narva Isthmus in 2 February – 10 August 1944. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Narva_%281944%29)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Uman–Botoşani Offensive - March 5 - April 17, 1944
properties.description:
The Uman–Botoşani Offensive was a part of the Dnieper–Carpathian Offensive , carried out by the Red Army in western Ukrainian SSR against the German Army Group South. The operation was successful, splitting the opposing Army Group in two and allowing the Soviet army to advance to the Dniester and Prut rivers in eastern Romania. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uman%E2%80%93Boto%C5%9Fani_Offensive)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Battle of the Kamenets-Podolsky Pocket - March 25 - April 15, 1944
properties.description:
The Battle of the Kamenets-Podolsky Pocket, also known as Hube's Pocket, was a Wehrmacht attempt on the Eastern Front of World War II to evade encirclement by the Red Army. During the Proskurov-Chernovtsy Offensive Operation (4 March 1944 - 17 April 1944) and the Uman-Botosani Offensive Operation (5 March 1944 - 17 April 1944) the 1st and 2nd Ukrainian Fronts encircled Generaloberst Hans-Valentin Hube's 1st Panzer Army north of the Dniestr river. The Panzer Army's personnel was largely able to escape the encirclement in April. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kamenets-Podolsky_Pocket)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: The Crimean Offensive - April 8 - May 12, 1944
properties.description:
The Crimean Offensive (8 April 1944 - 12 May 1944) – known in German sources as the Battle of the Crimea was a series of offensives by the Red Army in the effort to liberate Crimea from the German Wehrmacht occupation. The Red Army's 4th Ukrainian Front engaged German 17. Armee of Army Group South, which consisted of German and Romanian formations, in an operation to liberate the Crimean peninsula. The result of the battle was complete victory for the Red Army, and a botched evacuation effort across the Black Sea, leading to significant German and Romanian losses. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crimean_Offensive_Operation)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: First Battle of Târgu Frumos - April 9 - 12, 1944
properties.description:
The First Battle of Târgu Frumos was part of the First Jassy-Kishinev Offensive of World War II fought between Axis powers of World War II commanded by Otto Wöhler and Soviet forces led by Ivan Konev. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_Battle_of_T%C3%A2rgu_Frumos)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Battle of Podu Iloaiei - April 12, 1944
properties.description:
The Battle of Podu Iloaiei was part of the First Jassy-Kishinev Offensive of World War II fought between the Germans and the Soviets. The battle was a reaction to the Soviet defeat suffered at the First Battle of Târgu Frumos. In the end of the battle the Germans managed to drove the Soviets back to the positions held before the battle. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Podu_Iloaiei)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Second Battle of Târgu Frumos - May 2 - 8, 1944
properties.description:
The Second Battle of Târgu Frumos, part of the First Jassy-Kishinev Offensive, was a military engagement primarily between the Wehrmacht and Red Army forces in May 1944, near Iaşi, Romania.
(Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Second_Battle_of_T%C3%A2rgu_Frumos)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: D-Day, Operation Overlord - June 6 - August 30, 1944
properties.description:
Operation Overlord was the code name for the invasion of western Europe during World War II by Allied forces. The operation began on 6 June 1944 with the Normandy Landings (commonly known as D-Day) when an airborne assault preceded an amphibious assault. Nearly 160,000 troops crossed the English Channel on 6 June, and more than 3 million troops had landed by the end of August. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Operation_Overlord)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Pointe du Hoc - June 6, 1944
properties.description:
Pointe du Hoc is a clifftop location on the coast of Normandy in northern France. It lies 4 miles (6.4 km) west of Omaha Beach, and stands on 100 ft (30 m) tall cliffs overlooking the sea. It was a point of attack by the United States Army Ranger Assault Group during Operation Overlord in World War II. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pointe_du_Hoc)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Omaha Beach - June 6, 1944
properties.description:
Omaha Beach is the code name for one of the main landing points of the Allied invasion of German-occupied France in the Normandy landings on June 6 1944, during World War II. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Omaha_Beach)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Sword Beach - June 6, 1944
properties.description:
Sword Beach was the codename of one of the five main landing beaches in Operation Neptune, which was the initial assault phase of Operation Overlord (the Allied invasion of Normandy on 6 June 1944). Stretching 8 km from Ouistreham to Saint-Aubin-sur-Mer it was the farthest east of the landing points and around 15 km from Caen. The initial landings were achieved with low casualties, but the British forces ran into heavily defended areas behind the beachhead. The British landings were the only Allied sectors that faced attack by German Panzer Divisions on 6 June 1944. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sword_Beach)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Juno Beach - June 6, 1944
properties.description:
Juno Beach was one of the five main landing sites of the Allied invasion of the coast of Normandy on D-Day during World War II. It was situated between Sword Beach and Gold Beach. It is also known as the Canadian beach, as it was assigned to the 3rd Canadian Infantry Division. Despite being assigned to the Canadians, significant British forces were also present at Juno Beach. The naval component of the invasion force was known as Force J. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Juno_Beach)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Utah Beach - June 6, 1944
properties.description:
Utah Beach was the codename for the right flank or westernmost of the Allied landing beaches during the D-Day invasion of Normandy, as part of Operation Overlord on 6 June 1944. Utah was added to the invasion plan toward the end of the planning stages, when more landing craft became available. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Utah_Beach)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Gold Beach - June 6, 1944
properties.description:
Gold Beach was the code name for one of the central D-Day landing beaches that Allied forces used to invade German-occupied France on June 6, 1944, during World War II. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gold_Beach)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Battle for Caen - June 6 - August 6, 1944
properties.description:
The Battle for Caen from June to August 1944 was a battle between Allied (primarily British and Canadian troops) and German forces during the Battle of Normandy. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_for_Caen)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Battle of Cherbourg - June 6 - 30, 1944
properties.description:
The Battle of Cherbourg was part of the Battle of Normandy during World War II. It was fought immediately after the successful Allied landings on June 6, 1944. American troops isolated and then captured the fortified port, considered vital to the campaign in Western Europe, in a hard-fought campaign of three weeks. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Cherbourg)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Operation Perch - June 7 - June 14, 1944
properties.description:
Operation Perch was a British offensive of the Second World War which took place between 7 and 14 June 1944, during the Battle of Normandy. The operation was intended to encircle and seize the German occupied city of Caen, which was a major Allied objective in the early stages of the invasion of northwest Europe. A combination of fierce German resistance and failures at the British command level foiled the operation before its objectives were achieved.. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Operation_Perch)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Vyborg–Petrozavodsk Offensive - June 9 - August 9, 1944
properties.description:
During World War II, in the Continuation War, the Vyborg–Petrozavodsk Offensive was a strategic offensive by the Leningrad and Karelian Fronts against Finland on the Karelian Isthmus and East Karelia fronts. The operation ended in stalemate. The Soviets captured most of East Karelia and Vyborg (Viipuri), and were also successful in drawing further German forces away from Army Group Centre and weakened the German position in Belorussia before the launch of Operation Bagration. However they did not achieve the objective of Kymi River and the destruction of the Finnish army. This was the largest operation in scope and scale ever fought in the Nordic countries. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vyborg%E2%80%93Petrozavodsk_Offensive)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Battle of Le Mesnil-Patry - June 11, 1944
properties.description:
The battle of Le Mesnil-Patry was the last major combat operation conducted by Canadian land forces in Normandy during the month of June 1944. The Queen's Own Rifles of Canada, supported by the 6th Canadian Armoured Regiment (1st Hussars) attempted to take the town of Le Mesnil-Patry in Normandy as part of a southwards move towards high ground as part of the overall strategic goal of taking the city of Caen. The battle resulted in a German victory. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Le_Mesnil-Patry)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Battle of Villers-Bocage - June 13, 1944
properties.description:
The Battle of Villers-Bocage was a Second World War battle fought on 13 June 1944 during the Battle of Normandy. British armoured forces planned to seize the town as part of Operation Perch, an operation that intended to encircle and seize the German occupied city of Caen, which was a D-Day objective during invasion of northwest Europe. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Villers-Bocage)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Operation Bagration - June 22 - August 19, 1944
properties.description:
Operation Bagration was the codename for the Soviet 1944 Belorussian Strategic Offensive Operation during World War II, which cleared German forces from the Belorussian SSR and eastern Poland between 22 June 1944 and 19 August 1944. This action resulted in the almost complete destruction of the German Army Group Centre and three of its component armies: Fourth Army, Third Panzer Army and Ninth Army. By the end of the operation most of the western Soviet Union had been liberated and the Red Army had achieved footholds in Romania and Poland.
(Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Operation_Bagration)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Vitebsk-Orsha Offensive - June 23 - 28, 1944
properties.description:
The Vitebsk-Orsha Offensive was part of the Belorussian Strategic Offensive of the Red Army in summer 1944, commonly known as Operation Bagration. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vitebsk%E2%80%93Orsha_Offensive)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Mogilev Offensive - June 23 - 28, 1944
properties.description:
The Mogilev Offensive was part of the Belorussian Strategic Offensive of the Red Army in summer 1944, commonly known as Operation Bagration. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mogilev_Offensive)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Bobruysk Offensive - June 23 - 28, 1944
properties.description:
The Bobruysk Offensive was part of the Belorussian Strategic Offensive of the Red Army in summer 1944, commonly known as Operation Bagration. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bobruysk_Offensive)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Operation Martlet - June 25 - July 1, 1944
properties.description:
Operation Martlet (also known as Operation Dauntless) was the name given to the diversionary operation undertaken on 25 June 1944 by the 49th (West Riding) Infantry Division of XXX Corps to support Operation Epsom, the assault by the British VIII Corps into the Odon Valley. The Division's role was to provide flank security for the advancing VIII Corps and to ward off any counter-attacks. It was its first combat operation of the war. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Operation_Martlet)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Battle of Tali-Ihantala - June 25 - July 9, 1944
properties.description:
The Battle of Tali-Ihantala (June 25 to July 9, 1944) was part of the Continuation War (1941-1944) that occurred during World War II. The battle was fought by Finland, supported by forces of Germany against the Soviet Union and is to date the largest battle in history of the Nordic countries. The battle ended in a decisive Finnish victory. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Tali-Ihantala)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Operation Epsom - June 26 - 30, 1944
properties.description:
Operation Epsom, also known as the First Battle of the Odon, was a Second World War British offensive that took place between 26 and 30 June 1944, during the Battle of Normandy. The offensive was intended to outflank and seize the German-occupied city of Caen, a major Allied objective in the early stages of the invasion of northwest Europe. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Operation_Epsom)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Polotsk Offensive - June 29 - July 4, 1944
properties.description:
The Polotsk Offensive had the dual objective of taking Polotsk itself, and of screening the northern flank of the main Minsk Offensive against a possible German counter-offensive from Army Group North.
(Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polotsk_Offensive)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Minsk Offensive - June 29 - July 4, 1944
properties.description:
In twelve days, 22 June - 4 July 1944, the German Army Group Centre lost 25 divisions and 300,000 men. In the few subsequent weeks the Germans lost another 100,000 men. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Minsk_Offensive)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Operation Windsor - July 4 - 5, 1944
properties.description:
Operation Windsor was a Canadian offensive launched as part of the Battle of Normandy during World War II. Taking place between 4–5 July 1944, the attack was undertaken by the 3rd Canadian Infantry Division in an attempt to capture the Norman town of Carpiquet—as well as the adjacent airfield—from German forces. The attack was originally intended to take place during the later stages of Operation Epsom, as a method of protecting the eastern flank of the main assault. It was postponed and launched the following week. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Operation_Windsor)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Battle of the Bay of Vyborg - July 4 - 10, 1944
properties.description:
The Battle of the Bay of Vyborg (Finnish: Viipurinlahden taistelu) was a battle in the Finnish-Soviet Continuation War (1941-1944). The Battle took place when the Soviet 59th Army attacked across the islands of the Bay of Vyborg from July 4, 1944, on, in an attempt to knock the Finns outof the war. The Soviet attack to the Finnish mainland was thrown back to the sea by the German 122nd Division of the V AK on July 10, 1944. Their superior-range artillery and mortars repressed the main offensive, slowing it effectively.
(Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_the_Bay_of_Vyborg)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Battle of Vuosalmi - July 4 - 11, 1944
properties.description:
The Battle of Vuosalmi — the main bulk of it — lasted from July 4 to July 11, 1944. It was fought during the Continuation War (1941–1944), a part of World War II, between Finland and the Soviet Union. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Vuosalmi)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Vilnius Offensive - July 5 - 13, 1944
properties.description:
The Vilnius Offensive occurred as part of the third phase of Operation Bagration, the great summer offensive by the Red Army against the Wehrmacht in June and July, 1944. The Vilnius Offensive lasted from the 5th to the 13th of July, 1944, and ended with a Soviet victory. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vilnius_Offensive)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Belostock Offensive - July 5 - 27, 1944
properties.description:
The Belostock Offensive was part of the third and final phase of the Belorussian Strategic Offensive of the Red Army in summer 1944, commonly known as Operation Bagration. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Belostock_Offensive)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Shyaulyay Offensive - July 5 - August 29, 1944
properties.description:
The Shyaulyay Offensive was an operation of the Soviet forces of the 1st Baltic Front, commanded by General Hovhannes Bagramyan, conducted from July 5 to August 29, 1944 during the Second World War. It was part of the third phase of the Belorussian Strategic Offensive Operation (also known as Operation Bagration), and drove German troops from much of Lithuania, with the main tactical objective of the city of Šiauliai. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shyaulyay_Offensive_Operation)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Operation Charnwood - July 8 - 9, 1944
properties.description:
Operation Charnwood was a Second World War Anglo-Canadian offensive that took place from 8–9 July 1944, during the Battle of Normandy. The operation was intended to capture the German-occupied city of Caen, which was a major Allied objective during the opening stages of Operation Overlord. It was also hoped that the attack would pre-empt the transfer of German armoured units from the Anglo-Canadian sector to the lightly-screened American sector, where the eventual Allied breakout was to be engineered. The British and Canadians advanced on a broad front and by the evening of the second day had taken the northern half of Caen, up to the Orne and Odon rivers. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Operation_Charnwood)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Operation Jupiter - July 10 - 12, 1944
properties.description:
Operation Jupiter was an attack launched by the British Second Army's VIII Corps on 10 July. The objective of the attack was to capture the villages of Baron-sur-Odon, Fontaine-Étoupefour, Chateau de Fontaine and recapture Hill 112. Following the capture of these objectives the Corps would then capture Éterville and the village of Maltot and the ground up to the River Orne. Tanks from the 4th Armoured Brigade, supported by infantry, would then advance through the captured ground and secure several further villages to the west of the River Orne. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Operation_Jupiter_%281944%29)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Lvov-Sandomierz Offensive - July 13 - 29, 1944
properties.description:
The Lvov-Sandomierz Offensive or the L'vov-Sandomierz Strategic Offensive Operation was a major Red Army operation to force the German troops from Ukraine and Eastern Poland. Launched in mid July 1944, in just under one month of fighting, the Red Army achieved their objectives. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lvov%E2%80%93Sandomierz_Offensive)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Battle of Nietjärvi - July 15 - 17, 1944
properties.description:
The Battle of Nietjärvi (July 15 to July 17, 1944) was part of the Continuation War (1941–1944) — between Finland and the Soviet Union, which occurred during the World War II. The battle ended in a decisive Finnish victory, which ultimately helped to ensure Finland's continuous independence. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Nietj%C3%A4rvi)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Battle of Ancona - July 16 - 18, 1944
properties.description:
The Battle of Ancona was a battle involving forces from Poland serving as part of the British Army and German forces that took place between 16 June–18 July 1944 during the Italian campaign in World War II. The battle was the result of an Allied plan to capture the city of Ancona in Italy in order to gain possession of a seaport closer to the fighting so that they could shorten their lines of communication. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Ancona)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Operation Goodwood - July 18 - 20, 1944
properties.description:
Operation Goodwood was an attack launched on 18 July 1944, during the Second World War, by the British army to the east of the city of Caen. British VIII Corps led the attack with three armoured divisions, supported by British I Corps on the eastern flank and the Canadian II Corps on the western flank, who were launching their own attack codenamed Operation Atlantic, to capture the remainder of Caen. At least one historian has called the operation the largest tank battle that the British Army has ever fought. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Operation_Goodwood)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Operation Atlantic - July 18 - 20, 1944
properties.description:
Operation Atlantic was a Canadian offensive during the Battle of Normandy; launched in conjunction with Operation Goodwood, from July 18–20, 1944. Although initially successful, with gains made on the flanks of the Orne River near Saint-André-sur-Orne, an attack by the 4th & 6th Canadian Infantry Brigades against strongly defended positions on Verrières Ridge resulted in heavy casualties and limited strategic gain. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Operation_Atlantic)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Lublin–Brest Offensive - July 18 - August 2, 1944
properties.description:
The Lublin–Brest Offensive (18 July – 2 August 1944) was a part of the Operation Bagration strategic offensive by Soviet forces to clear Germans from central‐eastern Poland. The offensive was executed by the left (southern) wing of the 1st Belorussian Front and took place during July 1944; it was opposed by the German Army Group South Ukraine and Army Group Centre. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lublin-Brest_Offensive)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Battle of Verrières Ridge - July 19 - 24, 1944
properties.description:
The Battle of Verrières Ridge was a series of engagements fought as part of the Battle of Normandy, in western France, during the Second World War. The main combatants were two Canadian infantry divisions, with additional support from the 2nd Canadian Armoured Brigade, against elements of three German SS Panzer divisions. The battle was part of the British and Canadian attempts to break out of Caen, being part of both Operation Atlantic and Operation Spring. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Verri%C3%A8res_Ridge)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Battle of Auvere - July 20 - 25, 1944
properties.description:
Battle of Auvere was a battle in Estonia, stating on July 20, 1944 and ending on July 25. The battle was a part of the World War II campaign in Narva. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Auvere)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Operation Spring - July 25 - 27, 1944
properties.description:
Operation Spring was an offensive operation conducted by II Canadian Corps during the Normandy campaign. The plan was intended to create pressure on the German forces operating on the British and Canadian front simultaneously to American offensive operations in their sector known as Operation Cobra, an attempt to break out from the Normandy lodgement. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Operation_Spring)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Second Battle of the Odon - July 25 - 27, 1944
properties.description:
The Second Battle of the Odon was a series of operations fought by the British Army in mid July 1944 against the German Army as part of the Battle of Normandy. The two operations launched, Greenline and Pomegranate, were designed to draw German attention away from the upcoming assault, out of the Orne bridgehead, codenamed Goodwood. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Second_Battle_of_the_Odon)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Operation Cobra - July 25 - 31, 1944
properties.description:
Operation Cobra was General Omar Bradley's intention to take advantage of the German preoccupation with British and Canadian activity around the town of Caen, and punch through the German defenses. After a slow start the offensive gathered momentum, and German resistance collapsed as scattered remnants of broken units fought to escape to the Seine. Lacking the resources to cope with the situation, the German response was ineffectual, and the entire Normandy front soon collapsed. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Operation_Cobra)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Battle of Tannenberg Line - July 25 - August 10, 1944
properties.description:
The Battle of Tannenberg Line was a campaign between the German the army detachment "Narwa" and the Soviet Leningrad Front fought for the strategically important Narva Isthmus from 25 July to 10 August 1944. The campaign was fought on the Eastern Front during World War II. The strategic aim of the Soviet Estonian Operation was to reoccupy Estonia as a favourable basis for invasions of Finland and East-Prussia. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Tannenberg_Line)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Battle of Ilomantsi - July 26 - August 13, 1944
properties.description:
The Battle of Ilomantsi was a part of the Continuation War (1941–1944). It was fought from July 26 to August 13, 1944, between Finland and the Soviet Union. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Ilomantsi)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Kaunas Offensive - July 28 - August  28, 1944
properties.description:
The Kaunas Offensive was part of the third phase of the Belorussian Strategic Offensive of the Red Army in summer 1944, commonly known as Operation Bagration. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kaunas_Offensive_Operation)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Operation Bluecoat - July 30 - August 7, 1944
properties.description:
Operation Bluecoat was an attack by the British Second Army at the Battle of Normandy during World War II, from 30 July 1944 to 7 August 1944. The geographical objectives of the attack were to secure the key road junction of Vire and the high ground of Mont Pinçon. Strategically, the attack was made to support the American exploitation of their breakout on the western flank of the Normandy beachhead. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Operation_Bluecoat)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Battle of Radzymin - August 1 - 10, 1944
properties.description:
The Battle of Radzymin was one of a series of engagements between the Red Army's 1st Byelorussian Front and the Wehrmacht Heer's XXXIXth Panzer Corps that occurred as part of the Lublin-Brest Offensive between August 1 and August 10, 1944 at the conclusion of the Belorussian strategic offensive operation near the town of Radzymin in the vicinity of Warsaw, part of which entailed a large tank battle at Wołomin. It was the largest tank battle on the territories of Poland during WWII. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Radzymin_%281944%29)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Osovets Offensive - August 6 - 14, 1944
properties.description:
This offensive covered the operations of 2nd Belorussian Front from 6 August to 14 August, after their completion of the Belostock Offensive, with the objective of the fortified area at Osowiec on one of the tributaries of the Narew River. The very large fortress complex there secured the approaches to East Prussia through the region's marshes. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Osovets_Offensive)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Operation Lüttich - August 7  - 13, 1944
properties.description:
Operation Lüttich was a codename given to a German counterattack during the Battle of Normandy, which took place around the American positions near Mortain from 7 August to 13 August, 1944. The offensive is also referred to in American and British histories of the Battle of Normandy simply as the Mortain counter-offensive. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Operation_L%C3%BCttich)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Operation Totalize - August 8 - 13, 1944
properties.description:
Operation Totalize was an offensive launched by Allied troops of the First Canadian Army during the later stages of the Operation Overlord. The intention was to break through the German defenses south of Caen on the eastern flank of the Allied positions in Normandy and exploit success by driving south to capture the high ground north of the city of Falaise. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Operation_Totalize)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Battle of Studzianki - August 9 - 16, 1944
properties.description:
The Battle of Studzianki, was a tactical engagement between the elements of the elements of the Red Army's 2nd Tank Army employed as the Cavalry mechanized group of the 1st Belorussian Front and elements of the German 9th Army of Army Group North Ukraine defending south of Warsaw. The battle was part of the Soviet Lublin-Brest Offensive Operation. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Studzianki)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Tartu Offensive - August 10 - September 6, 1944
properties.description:
The Tartu Offensive operation was the campaign fought over South Estonia in 1944. The Soviet tactical aim was to defeat the German 18th Army, capture the city of Tartu. From then on the Soviet command planned to reach the coast of the Bay of Riga and trap the army detachment "Narwa" in Estonia. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tartu_Offensive)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Battle of the Falaise Pocket - August 12 - 21, 1944
properties.description:
The battle of the Falaise Pocket, fought during the Second World War from 12–21 August 1944, was the decisive engagement of the Battle of Normandy. Taking its name from the area around the town of Falaise within which the German Seventh and Fifth Panzer Armies became encircled by the advancing Western Allies, the battle is also referred to as the Falaise Gap after the corridor which the Germans sought to maintain to allow their escape. The battle resulted in the destruction of the bulk of Germany's forces west of the River Seine, and opened the way to Paris and the German border. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Falaise_Pocket)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Operation Tractable - August 14 - 21, 1944
properties.description:
Operation Tractable was the final Canadian–Polish offensive to take place during the Battle of Normandy. Its aim was to capture the strategically important town of Falaise and subsequently the towns of Trun and Chambois. Despite a slow start to the offensive that was marked by limited gains north of Falaise, innovative tactics by Stanisław Maczek's Polish 1st Armoured Division during the drive for Chambois allowed for the Falaise gap to be partially closed by August 19, 1944, trapping close to 300,000 German soldiers in the Falaise Pocket. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Operation_Tractable)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Operation Dragoon - August 15, 1944
properties.description:
Operation Dragoon was the Allied invasion of southern France, on August 15, 1944, as part of World War II. The invasion took place between Toulon and Cannes. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Operation_Dragoon)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Operation Doppelkopf - August 16 - 27, 1944
properties.description:
Operation Doppelkopf and the following Operation Cäsar were German counter-offensives on the Eastern Front late in 1944 in the aftermath of the major Soviet advance in Operation Bagration. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Operation_Doppelkopf)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Jassy-Kishinev Operation - August 20 - 29, 1944
properties.description:
The Jassy-Kishinev Operation is named after the two major cities (Iaşi and Chişinău) that define its staging area, was a Soviet offensive against Axis forces, which took place in Eastern Romania during 20-29 August 1944. The 2nd and 3rd Ukrainian Fronts of the Red Army engaged Army Group South Ukraine, which consisted of combined German and Romanian formations, in an operation to reclaim the Moldavian SSR and destroy the Axis forces in the region, opening a way into Romania and the Balkans.
(Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jassy%E2%80%93Kishinev_Offensive)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Battle of Rimini - August 25 - September 30, 1944
properties.description:
The Battle of Rimini is a name used to describe Operation Olive, the main Allied offensive on the Gothic Line in August and September 1944. It has been described as the biggest battle of materials ever fought in Italy. Over 1,200,000 men participated in the battle, which was a victory for the Allies although they did not achieve the hoped for decisive breakthrough. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Rimini_%281944%29)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Battle of Gemmano - September 4 - 15, 1944
properties.description:
The Battle of Gemmano was fought between the German and Allied forces in World War II. It was part of the Allies' Operation Olive, the offensive in August 1944 on the Gothic Line, the German line of defence in the Apennines in northern Italy. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Gemmano)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Battle of Nancy - September 5 - 15, 1944
properties.description:
The Battle of Nancy in September 1944 was a ten-day battle on the Western Front of World War II in which the U.S. Third Army defeated German forces defending the approaches to Nancy and crossings over the Moselle River to the north and south of the city. The battle resulted in U.S. forces fighting their way across the Moselle and liberating Nancy. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Nancy_%281944%29)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Battle of the Dukla Pass - September 8 - October 28, 1944
properties.description:
Battle of the Dukla Pass was the scene of bitterly contested battle for the Dukla Pass (borderland between Poland and Slovakia) on the Eastern Front of World War II between Nazi Germany and Soviet Union in September-October 1944. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_the_Dukla_Pass)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Operation Astonia - September 10 - 12, 1944
properties.description:
Operation Astonia was a battle fought during the Siegfried Line Campaign of World War II from 10 September 1944 to 12 September 1944. The Allied objective of the operation was the capture of the German-held port of Le Havre. The attack on a fort described by Field Marshal Bernard Montgomery as "one of the strongest fortresses of the Atlantic Wall" was a combined attack with elements of both the Canadian and British armed forces and participation from naval and aviation units, and has been described as 'a model of combined operations', with the fort falling within three days of the first assault. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Operation_Astonia)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Riga Offensive - September 14 - October 24, 1944
properties.description:
The Riga Offensive was part of the larger Baltic Offensive on the Eastern Front during World War II. It took place late in 1944, and drove German forces from the city of Riga. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Riga_Offensive_%281944%29)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Operation Wellhit - September 17 - 22, 1944
properties.description:
Operation Wellhit was the World War II operation by the 3rd Canadian Division (Canadian 1st Army) to take the fortified port of Boulogne in northern France. At first, the 9th Canadian Infantry Brigade had hoped to take Boulogne as part of its advance up the coast. The defences, however, brought them to a halt five miles from the city. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Operation_Wellhit)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Operation Market Garden - September 17 - 25, 1944
properties.description:
Operation Market Garden was an Allied military operation, fought in the Netherlands and Germany in World War II. It was the largest airborne operation of all time. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Operation_Market_Garden)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Battle of Arnhem - September 17 - 26, 1944
properties.description:
The Battle of Arnhem was a famous Second World War military engagement fought in and around the Dutch towns of Arnhem, Oosterbeek, Wolfheze, Driel and the surrounding countryside from the 17–26 September 1944. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Arnhem)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Tallinn Offensive - September 17 - 26, 1944
properties.description:
The Tallinn Offensive was the Soviet strategic offensive operation corresponding to the German abandonment of mainland Estonia codenamed Operation "Aster" in the Eastern Front (World War II) in 17–26 September 1944. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tallinn_Offensive)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Battle of Hürtgen Forest - September 19, 1944 - February 10, 1945
properties.description:
The Battle of Hürtgen Forest is the name given to the series of fierce battles fought between U.S. and German forces during World War II in the Hürtgen Forest, which became the longest battle on German ground during World War II, and the longest single battle the U.S. Army has ever fought in its history. The battles took place between September 19, 1944, and February 10, 1945, over barely 50 square miles (129 km²), east of the Belgian–German border. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_H%C3%BCrtgen_Forest)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Moonsund Landing Operation - September 29 - November 24, 1944
properties.description:
The Moonsund Landing Operation, also known as the Moonzund landing operation, was an amphibious operation and offensive by the Red Army during World War II, taking place in late 1944. It was part of the Baltic Offensive, and was designed to clear German forces of Army Group North from the islands in East Baltic Sea, the Moonsund archipelago. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moonsund_Landing_Operation)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Battle of Overloon - September 30 - October 18, 1944
properties.description:
The Battle of Overloon was a Second World War battle between Allied forces and the German army which took place in and around the village of Overloon in the south-east of the Netherlands between September 30th and October 18th, 1944. The battle, which resulted in an Allied victory, ensued after the Allies launched Operation Aintree. The Allies went on to liberate the town of Venray. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Operation_Aintree)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Battle of Aachen - October 2 - 21, 1944
properties.description:
The Battle of Aachen was a battle in Aachen, Germany, which occurred between 2–21 October 1944.
(Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Aachen)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Battle of the Scheldt - October 2 - November 8, 1944
properties.description:
The Battle of the Scheldt was a series of military operations of the First Canadian Army, led by Lieutenant General Guy Simonds. The battle took place in northern Belgium and southwestern Netherlands during World War II from October 2, 1944 to November 8, 1944. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_the_Scheldt)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Battle of Memel - October 5, 1944 - January 28, 1945
properties.description:
The Battle of Memel or the Siege of Memel took place when the Soviets launched their Memel Offensive Operation in late 1944. The offensive led to a three-month blockade of German forces in a small bridgehead in the town and its port. The bridgehead was finally crushed as part of a subsequent offensive, the East Prussian Offensive of early 1945. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Memel)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Battle of Debrecen - October 6 - 28, 1944
properties.description:
The Battle of Debrecen, called by the Red Army the Debrecen Offensive Operation, (6 October - 28 October 1944) was conducted by the 2nd Ukrainian Front on the Eastern Front of World War II. It was opposed by Army Group South Ukraine's General Maximilian Fretter-Pico's 6th Army (II formation) and allied Hungarian VII Army Corps units which were forced to retreat some 160 kilometers, while opposing Marshal Rodion Malinovsky's 2nd Ukrainian Front which had Debrecen, Hungary as its strategic objective. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Debrecen)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Gumbinnen Operation - October 16 - 27, 1944
properties.description:
The Gumbinnen Operation was a Soviet offensive on the Eastern Front late in 1944, in which forces of the 3rd Belorussian Front attempted to penetrate the borders of East Prussia. The offensive failed, due to strong resistance by the Wehrmacht. As a result it is largely known through German accounts of the defence and because of the atrocities that were alleged to have been committed by troops of the 11th Guards Army, the so-called Nemmersdorf massacre. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gumbinnen_Operation)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: First Battle for Kesternich - December 14 - 16, 1944
properties.description:
Kesternich is a small village just inside the German border from Belgium. It was the site of two major battles during World War II. These battles are tied to the Siegfried Line Campaign, Battle of the Huertgen Forest, Battle of the Bulge, and Roer Dam Assault at the outset of Operation Lumberjack. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Kesternich)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Battle of the Bulge - December 16, 1944 - January 25, 1945
properties.description:
The Ardennes Offensive was a major German offensive launched towards the end of World War II through the forested Ardennes Mountains region of Belgium, France and Luxembourg on the Western Front. This German offensive was officially named the Ardennes-Alsace campaign by the U.S. Army,but it is known to the general public simply as the Battle of the Bulge. The “bulge” was the initial incursion the Germans put into the Allies’ line of advance, as seen in maps presented in contemporary newspapers. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_the_Bulge)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Battle of Elsenborn Ridge - December 16 - 26, 1944
properties.description:
The Elsenborn Ridge is a ridge line east of the town of Elsenborn, Belgium in the Ardennes forest that is notable for its role in the Battle of the Bulge. Members of the inexperienced American 99th and the veterans of the 1st and 2nd Infantry Divisions defended against the German Army's spearhead forces, preventing them from reaching the road network west of the Elsenborn Ridge and the Meuse River. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_elsenborn_ridge)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Battle of Lanzareth Ridge - December 16, 1944
properties.description:
The Battle of Lanzareth ridge was part of the broader Battle of the Bulge. On the first day, the Germans attacked a ridge four miles from the town of Lanzareth, Belgium. The Germans launched a full-out attack with artillery support against American Infantry dug in along the ridge. Armour was also used to break through the defense, which had little in the way of AT guns or other heavy equipment. The end result was a wholesale German victory that brought early optimism. (Source: Wikipedia) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Lanzareth_ridge)

More World War II Resources:
http://www.everythingworldwar2.com

properties.name: Siege of Bastogne - December 20 - 27, 1944
properties.description:
